Glossary.Python: A high-level, interpreted programming language known for its readability and broad applicability in fields such as data science, web development, and automation.
Glossary.Java: A class-based, object-oriented programming language designed to be portable across platforms.
Glossary.C++: An extension of C programming language that includes object-oriented, generic, and functional features.
Glossary.Ruby: A dynamic, open-source programming language with a focus on simplicity and productivity.
Glossary.Swift: A programming language developed by Apple for iOS and macOS development.
Glossary.PHP: A popular general-purpose scripting language especially suited for web development.
Glossary.TypeScript: A strict syntactical superset of JavaScript that adds optional static typing.
Glossary.Kotlin: A modern programming language that interoperates with Java and is used for Android development.
Glossary.R: A programming language and environment commonly used for statistical computing and graphics.
Glossary.JavaScript: JavaScript is the world's most popular programming language
Glossary.CSS: CSS is the language we use to style an HTML document.
Glossary.React: A JavaScript library for building user interfaces.
Glossary.Angular: A TypeScript-based open-source web application framework developed by Google.
Glossary.Vue.js: An open-source JavaScript framework for building user interfaces and single-page applications.
Glossary.Django: A high-level Python web framework that encourages rapid development and clean, pragmatic design.
Glossary.Flask: A micro web framework written in Python, known for its simplicity and flexibility.
Glossary.Spring: A powerful, lightweight Java framework used for building enterprise-level applications.
Glossary.Express.js: A minimal and flexible Node.js web application framework providing robust features for web and mobile applications.
Glossary.Laravel: A PHP framework that provides an elegant syntax and tools for web application development.
Glossary.Ruby on Rails: A server-side web application framework written in Ruby.
Glossary.SQL: Structured Query Language, a standard language for managing relational databases.
Glossary.MongoDB: A NoSQL database known for its flexibility and scalability in handling large datasets.
Glossary.PostgreSQL: An advanced, open-source relational database known for its reliability and feature set.
Glossary.Firebase: A platform developed by Google for creating mobile and web applications, offering real-time database features.
Glossary.SQLite: A self-contained, high-reliability, embedded, full-featured SQL database engine.
Glossary.Yesterday: Refers to the day before the current day.
Glossary.Tomorrow: Refers to the day after the current day.
Glossary.Midnight: 12:00 AM, the start of a new day.
Glossary.Hour: A unit of time equal to 60 minutes.
Glossary.Minute: A unit of time equal to 60 seconds.
Glossary.Second: A base unit of time in the International System of Units (SI).
Glossary.Algorithm: A process or set of rules to be followed in calculations or other problem-solving operations, especially by a computer.
Glossary.Function: A block of organized, reusable code used to perform a single, related action.
Glossary.Variable: A storage location identified by a memory address and a symbolic name, which contains some known or unknown quantity of information referred to as a value.
Glossary.Loop: A programming construct that repeats a block of code until a certain condition is met.
Glossary.Array: A collection of items stored at contiguous memory locations.
Glossary.Class: A blueprint for creating objects, providing initial values for state and implementations of behavior.
Glossary.Object: An instance of a class, containing data and methods to operate on that data.
Glossary.Monday: The first day of the week in many cultures, often considered the start of the work week.
Glossary.Tuesday: The second day of the week.
Glossary.Wednesday: The third day of the week, commonly referred to as 'hump day.'
Glossary.Thursday: The fourth day of the week.
Glossary.Friday: The fifth day of the week, often associated with the end of the work week.
Glossary.Saturday: The sixth day of the week, commonly a weekend day.
Glossary.Sunday: The seventh day of the week, commonly a weekend day and often a day of rest.
Glossary.January: The first month of the year.
Glossary.February: The second month of the year, known for Valentine's Day.
Glossary.March: The third month of the year.
Glossary.April: The fourth month of the year.
Glossary.May: The fifth month of the year.
Glossary.June: The sixth month of the year.
Glossary.July: The seventh month of the year.
Glossary.August: The eighth month of the year.
Glossary.September: The ninth month of the year.
Glossary.October: The tenth month of the year, known for Halloween.
Glossary.November: The eleventh month of the year, known for Thanksgiving in the United States.
Glossary.December: The twelfth month of the year, known for winter holidays such as Christmas.
Glossary.AM: Indicates time from midnight to noon in the 12-hour clock system.
Glossary.PM: Indicates time from noon to midnight in the 12-hour clock system.
